HDG.BC.content: elucidation of what the Greek word says to us is not lacking [?] > German language: suited like no other for translating ancient Greek
HDG.BC.linkedContent: elucidation of what the Greek word says to us is not lacking [?] > German language: suited like no other for translating ancient Greek

HDG.FS.content: logos as gathering, “projects itself toward things that appear in their gathering” > for Greek thought, presencing of human is opening inception for oppositional presencing of World > alētheia: encounter (Begegnung) btwn that which presences and being is a self-opening, welcomes (Empfang) presence [a site, Ort?] > alētheia can’t be translated as truth
HDG.FS.linkedContent: logos as gathering, “projects itself toward things that appear in their gathering” > for Greek thought, presencing of human is opening inception for oppositional presencing of World > alētheia: encounter (Begegnung) btwn that which presences and being is a self-opening, welcomes (Empfang) presence [a site, Ort?] > alētheia can’t be translated as truth

HDG.FS.content: Latin translation of energeia by actus led to “making” as “creatio,” source of creation story
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Latin translation of energeia by actus led to “making” as “creatio,” source of creation story

HDG.FS.content: “Time and Being” thought “letting” as “giving (Geben)” > giving speaks in Es gibt (il y a too ontic of a translation, refers to presence of beings) > too ontic to understand Es Gibt as letting come to presence, as if it means “to make present” > rather think Es gibt re: letting itself, presence no longer emphasized: “to let the presencing (Lassen das Anwesen)” [still presence there?] (presence of a being no long draws one’s attention but ground the being covers over to stand independent) > letting as gift (Gabe), gives only its gift, withdraws/holds back (verbirgt)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: “Time and Being” thought “letting” as “giving (Geben)” > giving speaks in Es gibt (il y a too ontic of a translation, refers to presence of beings) > too ontic to understand Es Gibt as letting come to presence, as if it means “to make present” > rather think Es gibt re: letting itself, presence no longer emphasized: “to let the presencing (Lassen das Anwesen)” [still presence there?] (presence of a being no long draws one’s attention but ground the being covers over to stand independent) > letting as gift (Gabe), gives only its gift, withdraws/holds back (verbirgt)

HDG.FS.content: scholastic word objectum is translation of Greek word antikeimenon, but keisthai of antikeimenon means already lying before > whereas object, via representation, brought to halt in an “over and against (im Gegenüber)” > Greek experience of already lying before (and from itself) doesn’t require representation play role in positing being > Aristotle interprets phusis from poiēsis, bringing-forth into open—not modern notion of production (set into availability [Herstellen in die Verfügbarkeit])
HDG.FS.linkedContent: scholastic word objectum is translation of Greek word antikeimenon, but keisthai of antikeimenon means already lying before > whereas object, via representation, brought to halt in an “over and against (im Gegenüber)” > Greek experience of already lying before (and from itself) doesn’t require representation play role in positing being > Aristotle interprets phusis from poiēsis, bringing-forth into open—not modern notion of production (set into availability [Herstellen in die Verfügbarkeit])

HDG.DL.content: nature of German language must have come over him like a waterfall (Sturzbach), when Japaner translated “Letter on Humanism,” Hölderlin’s “Homecoming,” Kleist’s Penthesilea and Amphityron > while translating, sensed wellspring of reality (Wesensquell) was the same for the fundamentally different (grundverschiedenen) languages
HDG.DL.linkedContent: nature of German language must have come over him like a waterfall (Sturzbach), when Japaner translated “Letter on Humanism,” Hölderlin’s “Homecoming,” Kleist’s Penthesilea and Amphityron > while translating, sensed wellspring of reality (Wesensquell) was the same for the fundamentally different (grundverschiedenen) languages

HDG.EC.content: in accustomed translation of mortality, it’s the relation to death, not to the immortals, that is named > only man, not animal, knows death, can go towards death > animal cannot die, cannot have death
HDG.EC.linkedContent: in accustomed translation of mortality, it’s the relation to death, not to the immortals, that is named > only man, not animal, knows death, can go towards death > animal cannot die, cannot have death

HDG.OHF.content: hermeneutics as translation, hermeneutics [via Christian Churches] as commentary (enarratio), as exegesis > [Augustine on hermeneutics of scripture]
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: hermeneutics as translation, hermeneutics [via Christian Churches] as commentary (enarratio), as exegesis > [Augustine on hermeneutics of scripture]
